data.title: Revco will pay Eckerd $7.5 million to postpone its reorganization plan.
data.meta_description: Bankrupt Revco D.S. Inc.'s latest prescription for health calls for a $7.5 million payment to Jack Eckerd Corp. in exchange for Eckerd's pledge to shelve its rival reorganization plan indefinitely.
data.text:
Bankrupt Revco D.S. Inc.'s latest prescription for health calls for a $7.5 million payment to Jack Eckerd Corp. in exchange for Eckerd's pledge to shelve its rival reorganization plan indefinitely.

Revco is scheduled to appear in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Akron, Ohio, today for a hearing on its disclosure statement, a document similar to a prospectus, a Revco spokesman said yesterday. If judged complete, the disclosure statement and Revco's reorganization plan will be sent to creditors for a vote. The Twinsburg, Ohio-based drugstore chain filed its latest amended plan Wednesday.

The current schedule calls for creditors to return ballots by March 6 and a confirmation hearing on March 11, the spokesman said.

If all goes in Revco's favor, it could emerge from bankruptcy in mid-April, he said.

Revco is cautiously optimistic that the court will approve the document, the spokesman said. Both the disclosure statement and the plan have been on file for creditors to review, and few objections have surfaced.

"At this point in time, everybody is optimistic, but in these situations you can never be confident," he said.

The spokesman noted, however, that because the latest plan was only filed Wednesday, a "remote" possibility exists that creditors could submit a last-minute objection and seek to delay the procedure.

"It's unlikely that anybody would do that," he said. "It's a very remote possibility."

The spokesman also emphasized that Eckerd has postponed its plan, not withdrawn it. In the unlikely event that Eckerd reactivates its plan, it would forfeit the $7.5 million payment. The payment is to cover expenses Eckerd has incurred relating to its reorganization plan. Eckerd also would have to file a motion to reactivate the plan before Revco's plan is confirmed.

Eckerd's $7.5 million payment will be funded through the exercise of rights that Revco would issue to its subordinated debt holders. Each right would entitle the holder to purchase one share of new Revco common stock at $7.47 a share.

Zell-Chilmark Fund L.P., which has already pledged to buy for cash up to $250 million of common stock that would be issued to creditors under the reorganization plan, has also agreed to buy off common stock issued to fund the Eckerd payment that the subordinated debt holders decide not to purchase.

The more shares Zell buys, the greater its control over the company, the spokesman said.

"We believe this action -- which results in an uncontested Revoc plan -- will provide significant savings for Revco and present a realistic opportunity for the company to emerge from bankruptcy at an early date," Boake A. Sells, Revco chairman and chief executive officer, said in a release.

"Confirmation of the Eckerd plan would have resulted in significant additional costs to Eckerd and even further delays in this case," Stewart Turley, Eckerd's chairman, said in the release.

Revco filed for Chapter 11 provisions on July 28, 1988, burdened by $1.5 billion of debt resulting from a failed leveraged buyout by former management and other investors.

In secondary trading the high-yield bonds proved "surprisingly resilient," losing only 1/4 point in light of the equity and Treasury market's declines, a high-yield source said. Chrysler Corp. bonds continued to move up, gaining 1-1/4 to 1-1/2 points across the board. High-grades sank lower with Treasuries, which lost a point in the long end and 3/4 point in the 10-year sector.

New Issues

Century Communications Corp. issued $200 million of 9.750% variable-rate senior notes due 2002. Moody's Investor Service rates the noncallable notes B2, while Standard & Poor's Corp. rates them B. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. sole managed the offering.

Fair Lanes Inc. issued $138 million of 11.875% senior secured notes due Aug. 15, 1997. The notes are callable after Feb. 15, 1995 at 105 and at par after Feb. 15, 1996. The notes were priced to yield 99.504 to yield 12%. Moody's rates the offering B1, while Standard & Poor's rates it B. DLJ sole managed the offering.

In rating actions yesterday, Standard & Poor's lowered Lyondell Petrochemical Co.'s senior debt to BBB-minus from BBB and commercial paper to A-3 from A-2. Approximately $800 million of total debt is outstanding, the agency said in a release.

"The downgrades reflect the firm's higher-than-anticipated capital spending program and continued aggressive dividend policy in the face of a cyclic industry downturn," Standard & Poor's said. "Capital spending will jump from $43 million in 1991 to $115 million in 1992, as a result of several expansion and environmental projects," the release said.

Fitch Investors Service has assigned an A-plus rating to Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc.'s $3.6 billion of outstanding senior debt. That debt includes the company's recently offered $500 million for 7.875% notes due 2002, $250 million of 8.5% notes due 2012, and $750 million of 8.5% debentures due 2022. Fitch affirmed the company's commercial paper at F-1.

Fitch rated the company wholly owned Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group Inc.'s approximately $100 million of remaining outstanding subordinated debt A. The credit trend is stable
